questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of fatigue, dyspnea, and mild chest pain on exertion for 1 week. She does not have a fever or a rash. She had an upper respiratory infection 3 weeks ago. She returned from summer camp in Colorado 3 days ago. She says they went hiking and camping as part of their activities. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate is 96/min, and blood pressure is 106/74 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention and 1+ pitting edema on both ankles. A few scattered inspiratory crackles are heard in the thorax and an S3 gallop is heard at the apex. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8900/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h. An x-ray of the chest shows mild cardiac enlargement. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) typically affects children aged 5–15 years and develops within three weeks after streptococcal infection (e.g., group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis). Diagnosis is established using the revised Jones criteria (two major criteria or one major plus two minor criteria). Involvement of the cardiac system (e.g., myocarditis) is a major criterion. However, this patient does not have evidence of another major criterion (e.g., subcutaneous nodules, polyarthritis) or any minor criteria (e.g., high fever, elevated acute phase reactants, arthralgias), making a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Giant cell myocarditis (GCM) is a rare type of autoimmune myocarditis, which typically has a rapid onset and fulminant progression over the course of one or two days. GCM is unlikely in this patient, who has had mild to moderate symptoms for one week.

C) INCORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi infection is the cause of Lyme disease, which can result in symptomatic myocarditis (Lyme carditis). Moreover, some cases of Lyme disease do not manifest with signs of early localized disease (e.g., erythema migrans). However, Lyme carditis typically develops 3–10 weeks after a tick bite (early disseminated Lyme disease), whereas this patient returned from summer camp only 3 days ago. Furthermore, this patient has no history of travel to an endemic region (Northeast and Upper Midwest of the US).

D) CORRECT:

Myocarditis is most commonly caused by viral infections (e.g., Coxsackie B virus infection, parvovirus B19 infection, HHV-6 infection) and Coxsackie B virus is the most common cause of viral myocarditis in children and adolescents. Features of cardiac dysfunction may be preceded by signs of infection (e.g., flu-like symptoms, gastrointestinal symptoms). In children, myocarditis is rare and symptoms are often more severe than in adults, who typically have mild or even no symptoms. Children are also more often affected by complications (e.g., cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock) than adults and require careful management (e.g., cardiorespiratory monitoring, management of heart failure with diuretics).

Further management of this patient would include an ECG and echocardiography to assess the severity of cardiac dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus infection mainly affects infants and young children, but it can affect people of all ages. While it is theoretically possible that it was the cause of this patient's upper respiratory tract infection, it is not associated with myocarditis and, therefore, unlikely to have caused her present symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Although a rhinovirus infection may have caused this patient's upper respiratory tract infection, there are only a handful of reports of it being associated with myocarditis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of pulmonary congestion (dyspnea, inspiratory crackles) and increased central venous pressure (jugular venous distention, edema) as well as cardiac enlargement on chest x-ray, all of which suggest congestive heart failure (CHF). The combination of chest pain and a history of recent upper respiratory tract infection makes myocarditis the most likely cause of CHF in this patient.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of progressively worsening dyspnea. During this time, he also has had intermittent episodes of chest pain, which was 4/10 in intensity and increased on inspiration. He does triathlons and has not been able to train because of these symptoms. He has had no fever or syncopal episodes. He had an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. His father died of heart disease at the age of 55 years. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 113/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention. Inspiratory crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. On cardiac examination, an S3 gallop is heard. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9200/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
41 mm/h


Serum



Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Glucose
92 mg/dL


LDH
120 U/L


Troponin I
0.24 ng/mL


An x-ray of the chest shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette and prominent vascular markings in both lung fields. ECG shows diffuse T-wave inversions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is caused by right ventricular myocardial cell death leading to right ventricular wall thinning, dilation, and dysfunction. ARVC typically affects young adults (average age of diagnosis is 30 years) and causes symptoms of right heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distention). However, ARVC does not typically affect the left ventricle and is, therefore, inconsistent with this patient's features of left heart failure (e.g., inspiratory crackles, pulmonary congestion on x-ray).

B) INCORRECT:

Pericardial tamponade can be caused by a large pericardial effusion, for which viral myocarditis is a risk factor. This condition can cause hemodynamic compromise and jugular venous distention. However, other typical findings of pericardial tamponade include hypotension and distant heart sounds (see Beck triad). In addition, this condition typically causes low voltage and electrical alternans on ECG.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a hereditary disease and the leading cause of death in young athletes. This condition manifests with chest pain and dyspnea that worsen with strenuous exercise (due to reduced systolic output), which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, he is missing additional features of HCM, such as syncopal episodes, palpitations, and vertigo, and his ECG lacks signs of left ventricular hypertrophy (see Sokolow-Lyon criteria) or atrial fibrillation. Furthermore, jugular distention and inspiratory crackles are not expected in patients with HCM.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve stenosis can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) since the left ventricle chronically pumps against a high afterload. While this patient shows evidence of an enlarged left ventricle (enlarged cardiac silhouette), and LVH can cause T-wave inversions, he is otherwise young and healthy (no history of angina pectoris or syncopal episodes) and has no heart murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis can cause left atrial enlargement (LAE) and eventually progress to heart failure. However, mitral stenosis characteristically manifests with a low-pitched diastolic rumble and an opening snap. Additionally, mitral stenosis with subsequent LAE would cause P mitrale on ECG.

F) CORRECT:

Myocarditis has a wide range of clinical presentations, from subclinical (and often undiagnosed) myocarditis to dilated cardiomyopathy with features of acute decompensated heart failure, as seen in this patient. Myocarditis is most commonly caused by viral infections and most often affects young adults. If myocarditis is suspected, an ECG, cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponin), and chest x-ray should be obtained. ECG may show nonspecific signs of myocardial damage (e.g., T-wave inversions, tachycardia); cardiac biomarkers and inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) are typically elevated. Echocardiography is indicated to evaluate ventricular dysfunction. In patients with myocarditis complicated by dilated cardiomyopathy, echocardiography typically shows ventricular dilation and global ventricular hypokinesis.

G) INCORRECT:

Vegetations on the cardiac valves in the setting of bacterial endocarditis can lead to valvular insufficiency and subsequent heart failure. However, endocarditis typically causes constitutional symptoms and a heart murmur, which are not present here.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, jugular venous distention, tachycardia, an S3 gallop, inspiratory crackles, and x-ray findings of pulmonary congestion (e.g., increased vascular markings, cardiac enlargement) are consistent with decompensated heart failure (HF). In this young and otherwise healthy patient with a history of recent upper respiratory tract infection and chest pain that increases during inspiration (indicating pericardial involvement), HF is most likely secondary to viral myocarditis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of progressively worsening dyspnea and chest pain. He had an upper respiratory tract infection with cough and rhinorrhea 2 weeks ago. His pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination shows inspiratory crackles bilaterally. His serum troponin I concentration is 0.21 ng/mL. An x-ray of the chest shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette and prominent vascular markings in both lung fields. ECG shows nonspecific T wave changes and no evidence of low-voltage or changing QRS complex amplitude. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Sarcomere duplication in parallel on endomyocardial biopsy
Elevated brain natriuretic peptide concentration on serum studies
Opening snap with a diastolic murmur on cardiac auscultation
Elevated procalcitonin concentration on serum studies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sarcomere duplication in parallel occurs with hypertrophy of the cardiac chamber walls (e.g., due to chronic valvular disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). The typical cardiac histopathological change in viral myocarditis is focal necrosis with lymphocytic infiltration, and in a patient with DCM, the sarcomeric changes include myofilament disarray, sarcomere lengthening, and, possibly, sarcomere duplication in series, not parallel.

B) CORRECT:

In viral myocarditis, cardiomyocytes are damaged by virus-mediated lysis and immunological molecular mimicry and cross-reactivity. Commonly implicated viruses include coxsackie B, adenovirus, parvovirus B19, HIV, and HHV-6. Myocarditis has a broad range of clinical presentations, from subclinical (and often undiagnosed) myocarditis to DCM and acute heart failure, as seen in this patient. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) is a very sensitive marker for heart failure, as BNP is secreted by a stretched or overworked cardiac ventricle. Other complications of myocarditis include concurrent pericarditis (perimyocarditis), arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death.

C) INCORRECT:

An opening snap with a low-pitched diastolic murmur is the classic finding in mitral stenosis (MS), which can cause heart failure and, if chronic, left atrial enlargement (in the early stage) and right ventricular hypertrophy (in the late stage). The typical auscultatory findings in a patient with DCM include a systolic murmur (due to mitral regurgitation) and a loud S3.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum procalcitonin levels are seen with bacterial infections (e.g., bacterial pneumonia). Most cases of postinfectious myocarditis are the result of viral, not bacterial infection. Procalcitonin levels are not elevated with viral infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery occlusion is the cause of acute coronary syndrome, which can manifest with chest pain, troponin elevation, T wave changes, and congestive heart failure. A young patient, however, is unlikely to have clinically significant coronary artery disease and the history of recent upper respiratory tract infection makes a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Dyspnea with features of pulmonary edema (e.g., inspiratory crackles) and prominent vascular markings are consistent with congestive heart failure (CHF). The most likely cause of acute-onset CHF in this young adult with a recent upper respiratory tract infection is dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) secondary to viral myocarditis. Chest pain with elevated troponin levels and nonspecific T-wave changes are features of myocarditis, and DCM can manifest on a chest x-ray with an enlarged cardiac silhouette (due to balloon-like ventricular dilation).

questions.text: A previously healthy 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fevers, congestion, and chest pain for 3 days. The chest pain is exacerbated by deep inspiration. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg. He appears weak and lethargic. Cardiac examination shows a scratchy sound best heard along the left sternal border when the patient leans forward. There are crackles in both lung bases. Examination of the lower extremities shows pitting edema. Results of a rapid influenza test are negative. ECG shows diffuse ST-elevations with depressed PR interval. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular chamber enlargement with contractile dysfunction. Infection with which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with togaviruses (e.g., rubella virus, western and eastern equine encephalitis virus, chikungunya virus) is not a common cause of viral myocarditis or pericarditis. This patient lacks risk factors for Western and Eastern equine encephalitis and chikungunya virus (e.g., mosquito bites, travel to endemic areas), and has no signs of rubella infection (e.g., lymphadenopathy, polyarthritis, skin rash).

B) INCORRECT:

Infections with paramyxoviruses (e.g., parainfluenza virus, RSV, measles virus, mumps virus) can present with fever and congestion, as seen in this patient, but they do not commonly cause myocarditis or pericarditis. Croup, measles, and mumps are all caused by paramyxovirus infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Infections with flaviviruses (e.g., dengue virus, yellow fever virus, St. Louis encephalitis virus, West Nile virus, Zika virus, and hepatitis C virus) do not commonly cause myocarditis or pericarditis. Furthermore, this patient lacks typical symptoms and risk factors (e.g., exposure to Aedes aegypti mosquito, IV drug use, etc) for flavivirus infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Infections with orthomyxoviruses (e.g, influenza virus) can present with fever, lethargy, and congestion, as seen in this patient. While influenza is not a common cause of myocarditis, the H1N1 influenza A strain has been implicated in cases of fulminant myocarditis. This patient's negative influenza testing and lack of other typical symptoms (e.g., myalgias) make this unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Coxsackie B is one of the most commonly identified infectious causes of viral myocarditis. It belongs to the picornavirus family and is transmitted via airborne droplets or the fecal-oral route. Other viral pathogens that can cause myocarditis include parvovirus B19, HHV-6, HIV, and adenovirus.
questions.hint: This patient has evidence of both pericarditis and myocarditis (i.e., inflammation of the heart muscle and pericardium). The most commonly identified pathogen responsible for myocarditis belongs to the same family as poliovirus and echovirus.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man with no significant medical history is evaluated after reporting one week of progressive shortness of breath. He was in his usual state of health until 2 weeks before admission, when he experienced several days of low-grade fever, a nonproductive cough, rhinorrhea, and myalgias. During the past week, he has become short of breath on moderate levels of exertion and has noticed swelling in both lower extremities. He denies any chest pain.
The patient does not use tobacco or illicit drugs and reports drinking approximately 3 alcoholic beverages per week. His father has hypertension, and his mother has diet-controlled type 2 diabetes.
On examination, the patient is afebrile with a blood pressure of 108/59 mm Hg, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 91% while breathing ambient air. The heart rate is regular, with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Inspiratory crackles are evident in both lower lung fields. He has 2+ pitting, bilateral lower-extremity edema to the midshins.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
10,700
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
14.5
13.5–17.5


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.8–1.3


Troponin T (ng/mL) (4th-generation assay)
0.7
0–0.03


Brain natriuretic peptide (pg/mL)
1072
≤35


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
145
125–200


An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral-valve prolapse is associated with a click and a late systolic murmur. It is not associated with new-onset heart failure unless associated with mitral regurgitation.

B) CORRECT:

Myocarditis is an inflammatory disease of the heart muscle that can result from various infectious causes (viral, bacterial, fungal, protozoal, or helminthic) or noninfectious sources (autoimmune diseases, drug reactions, or toxins). Classically, cardiac myocytes are damaged acutely by viral entry and replication, leading to myocyte necrosis, followed by immune system activation and inflammation that may further damage the myocardium.

Patients with acute myocarditis can present with myriad symptoms, including chest pain, arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock. This patient has acute heart failure, evidence of myocardial injury, T-wave inversions on electrocardiogram, and a preceding viral syndrome.

Key learning point: In a patient with new-onset heart failure, cardiac biomarker elevation, and lack of traditional coronary risk factors, the differential diagnosis should include acute myocarditis, particularly if there is a history of preceding viral or infectious symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient lacks the usual symptoms (pleuritic chest pain) or electrocardiographic findings (i.e., diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression) of pericarditis, which alone does not typically cause cardiac biomarker elevations.

D) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic cardiomyopathy is not typically associated with elevated cardiac biomarkers.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial endocarditis is associated with nonspecific symptoms (such as fever, chills, malaise, weight loss, and joint pain); heart murmurs are detected in approximately 85% of patients with bacterial endocarditis, and stigmata of emboli may be present.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents for outpatient follow-up after being seen in the emergency department (ED) 7 days ago for fever and malaise. During that ED visit, he had a leukocyte count of 10,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 53 mm/hour (0–17); he was diagnosed with a viral illness and was discharged to home. Since then, his fever has resolved, but his appetite remains poor. He has had two episodes of emesis, and he continues to have intermittent abdominal pain and decreased energy. When he woke this morning, he felt that his heart was beating fast.
On examination, he appears fatigued with mild volume depletion but is in no acute distress. He has a heart rate of 145 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, an oxygen saturation of 96% while he breathes ambient air, and a normal blood pressure. His breath sounds are clear. He has soft first and second heart sounds, in addition to a systolic murmur heard best at the upper left sternal border. His abdomen is slightly distended but soft with normal bowel sounds; no masses are palpated.
In addition to basic laboratory evaluation, which one of the following tests is most likely to reveal the correct diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph should be included in the evaluation and may reveal an enlarged cardiac silhouette and pulmonary edema from diminished cardiac output, but it does not directly assess heart function or conduction, which are often affected in myocarditis.

B) CORRECT:

Postviral myocarditis should be considered in any patient who presents with a new cardiac murmur shortly after a viral illness.

The diagnosis of myocarditis is based on a combination of clinical and histologic criteria, including the presence of cellular infiltration with or without associated myocyte necrosis. Clinical diagnosis requires a high index of suspicion because the symptoms are often vague and are frequently respiratory or gastrointestinal in nature (shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and poor feeding) rather than cardiac (tachycardia, chest pain, syncope, pallor, and hypotension). Although inflammatory markers (leukocyte count, C-reactive protein level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate) may be elevated, they are nonspecific, and normal results do not exclude the diagnosis. Abnormalities in cardiac biomarkers, such as troponins, may be found in some patients but are not necessary for diagnosis. Given these complexities, many patients with myocarditis present multiple times before an accurate diagnosis is made.

Although a myocardial biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, less-invasive approaches are preferred for initial workup, because patients are often unstable, and invasive testing can confer unnecessary risk. Echocardiography can assess muscle function and valvular insufficiency and is therefore the most appropriate test for this patient.

A chest radiograph should be included in the evaluation and may reveal an enlarged cardiac silhouette and pulmonary edema from diminished cardiac output, but it does not directly assess heart function or conduction, which are often affected in myocarditis. Additionally, an electrocardiogram should be performed and is often abnormal with findings suggestive of myocarditis, but it will not definitively reveal the diagnosis.

Key learning point: The combination of tachycardia, abdominal pain, and a new cardiac murmur in a patient with a recent viral illness with fevers should raise concern for postviral myocarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although an abdominal radiograph, upper gastrointestinal series, and abdominal ultrasound would assist in identifying an obstruction or other abdominal pathological process, this patient’s abdominal pain is probably secondary to diminished cardiac output rather than a primary abdominal condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Although an abdominal radiograph, upper gastrointestinal series, and abdominal ultrasound would assist in identifying an obstruction or other abdominal pathological process, this patient’s abdominal pain is probably secondary to diminished cardiac output rather than a primary abdominal condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Although an abdominal radiograph, upper gastrointestinal series, and abdominal ultrasound would assist in identifying an obstruction or other abdominal pathological process, this patient’s abdominal pain is probably secondary to diminished cardiac output rather than a primary abdominal condition.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy presents for outpatient follow-up after being seen in the emergency department (ED) 7 days ago for fever and malaise. During that ED visit, he had a leukocyte count of 10,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–13,500) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 53 mm/hour (0–13); he was diagnosed with a viral illness and was discharged to home. Since then, his fever has resolved, but his appetite remains poor. He has had two episodes of emesis, and he continues to have intermittent abdominal pain and decreased energy. This morning, he awoke complaining that his heart was beating fast.
On examination, he appears fatigued with mild volume depletion but is in no acute distress. He has a heart rate of 145 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, an oxygen saturation of 96% while he breathes ambient air, and a normal blood pressure. His breath sounds are clear. He has soft first and second heart sounds, in addition to a systolic murmur heard best at the upper left sternal border. His abdomen is slightly distended but soft with normal bowel sounds; no masses are palpated.
In addition to basic laboratory evaluation, which one of the following tests is most likely to reveal the correct diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although an abdominal ultrasound would assist in identifying an obstruction or other abdominal pathological process, this patient’s abdominal pain is probably secondary to diminished cardiac output rather than a primary abdominal condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Although an abdominal radiograph would assist in identifying an obstruction or other abdominal pathological process, this patient’s abdominal pain is probably secondary to diminished cardiac output rather than a primary abdominal condition.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph should be included in the evaluation and may reveal an enlarged cardiac silhouette and pulmonary edema from diminished cardiac output, but it does not directly assess heart function or conduction. Additionally, an electrocardiogram should be performed and is often abnormal, but it will not definitively reveal the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Although an upper gastrointestinal series would assist in identifying an obstruction or other abdominal pathological process, this patient’s abdominal pain is probably secondary to diminished cardiac output rather than a primary abdominal condition.

E) CORRECT:

Postviral myocarditis should be considered in any child who presents with a new cardiac murmur shortly after a viral illness.

The diagnosis of myocarditis is based on a combination of clinical and histologic criteria, including the presence of cellular infiltration with or without associated myocyte necrosis. Clinical diagnosis requires a high index of suspicion because the symptoms are often vague and are frequently respiratory or gastrointestinal in nature (shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and poor feeding) rather than cardiac (tachycardia, chest pain, syncope, pallor, and hypotension). Although inflammatory markers (leukocyte count, C-reactive protein level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate) may be elevated, they are nonspecific, and normal results do not exclude the diagnosis. Abnormalities in cardiac biomarkers, such as troponins, may be found in some patients but are not necessary for diagnosis. Given these complexities, many patients with myocarditis present multiple times before an accurate diagnosis is made.

Although a myocardial biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, less-invasive approaches are preferred for initial workup, because patients are often unstable, and invasive testing can confer unnecessary risk. Echocardiography can assess muscle function and valvular insufficiency and is therefore the most appropriate test for this patient.

Key learning point: The combination of tachycardia, abdominal pain, and a new cardiac murmur in a child with a recent history of viral illness with fevers should raise concern for postviral myocarditis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is admitted from the emergency department (ED) for dehydration. Four days ago, he developed a fever (maximum temperature, 38.9°C), fussiness, loose stools, and diminished oral intake. His mother was concerned that he had a sore throat because he would cry whenever he tried to drink. In the ED, he was tachycardic, had dry mucous membranes, and refused all oral fluids. He is up to date with his immunizations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Given concerns about dehydration, he received a total fluid bolus of 40 mL/kg of normal saline and was placed on maintenance fluids overnight.
The next morning on the inpatient service, he appears ill with a heart rate of 156 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 53 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 95% while he breathes ambient air.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
13,000
5500–15,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11.0
11.5–13.5


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
140
0–5


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hour)
30
0–13


An electrocardiogram reveals a prolonged QT interval and diffuse ST-segment elevation. Additional testing reveals a troponin-I level of 208 ng/mL (reference range, <0.1) and a creatine kinase-MB level of 46 ng/mL (<7.7).
Which one of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fungi (Candida), protozoa (Trypanosoma cruzi), rickettsias, and spirochetes are less common causes of acute myocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacterial causes — including staphylococcus, streptococcus, and mycobacterium — are less frequently implicated in the etiology of acute myocarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the clinical manifestations of acute myocarditis may mimic those of a more common viral infection, such as influenza, this patient’s lack of respiratory symptoms and his worsening status should alert the clinician to myocarditis. Influenza virus has been identified as a cause of acute myocarditis, but not as commonly as enterovirus.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with acute myocarditis caused by a preceding viral infection.

Tachypnea and tachycardia are the most common presenting symptoms in patients with acute myocarditis. Gastrointestinal findings (anorexia, abdominal pain, and vomiting) may also occur, as well as chest pain, syncope, and palpitations. Other cardiac-specific symptoms, such as pallor and hypotension, are less common. Patients may have abnormal electrocardiographic findings, including ST-segment elevation, low-voltage QRS complexes, conduction delays, and other abnormalities. They may also have elevated levels of inflammatory biomarkers (leukocyte count, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate), but these biomarkers are nonspecific, and normal results do not exclude myocarditis. Elevated cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponin) may be seen in acute myocarditis but are not necessary for diagnosis. This patient has elevations in both inflammatory and cardiac biomarkers, raising concern for myocarditis. The diagnosis of acute myocarditis is challenging and relies on a combination of clinical and histologic criteria (cellular infiltration with or without associated myocyte necrosis).

In the United States, myocarditis typically stems from a viral infection; common pathogens include enterovirus (e.g., coxsackie virus), adenovirus, parvovirus, and human herpesvirus 6.

Key learning point: The pathogen most likely to cause acute myocarditis in children is an enterovirus.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial causes — including staphylococcus, streptococcus, and mycobacterium — are less frequently implicated in the etiology of acute myocarditis. Although the clinical manifestations of acute myocarditis may mimic those of a more common viral infection, such as influenza, this patient’s lack of respiratory symptoms and his worsening status should alert the clinician to myocarditis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of worsening dyspnea and intermittent episodes of chest pain, which increased on inspiration. He recently began training for a marathon and had an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse rate is 113/min, and blood pressure is 110/74 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and lower extremity edema. Inspiratory crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. On cardiac examination, an S3 gallop is heard. Chest x-ray study shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette and prominent vascular markings in both lung fields. Electrocardiography shows diffuse T-wave inversions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vegetations on the cardiac valves in the setting of bacterial endocarditis can lead to valvular insufficiency and subsequent heart failure. However, endocarditis typically causes constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever) and a heart murmur, which are not present here.

B) INCORRECT:

Pericardial tamponade can be caused by a large pericardial effusion, for which viral myocarditis is a risk factor. This condition can cause hemodynamic compromise and jugular venous distention. However, other typical findings of pericardial tamponade include hypotension and distant heart sounds (see Beck triad). In addition, this condition typically causes low voltage and electrical alternans on ECG.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a hereditary disease and the leading cause of death in young athletes. This condition manifests with chest pain and dyspnea that worsen with strenuous exercise (due to reduced systolic output), which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, he is missing additional features of HCM, such as syncopal episodes, palpitations, and vertigo, and his ECG lacks signs of left ventricular hypertrophy (see Sokolow-Lyon criteria) or atrial fibrillation. Furthermore, jugular distention and inspiratory crackles are not expected in patients with HCM.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve stenosis can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) since the left ventricle chronically pumps against a high afterload. While this patient shows signs of an enlarged left ventricle (enlarged cardiac silhouette), and LVH can cause T-wave inversions, he is otherwise young and healthy (no history of angina pectoris or syncopal episodes) and has no heart murmur.

E) CORRECT:

Myocarditis has a wide range of clinical presentations, from subclinical (and often undiagnosed) myocarditis to dilated cardiomyopathy with features of acute decompensated heart failure, as seen in this patient. Myocarditis is most commonly caused by viral infections and most often affects young adults. If myocarditis is suspected, an ECG, cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponin), and chest x-ray should be obtained. ECG may show nonspecific signs of myocardial damage (e.g., T-wave inversions, tachycardia); cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponin I) and inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) are typically elevated. Echocardiography is indicated to evaluate ventricular dysfunction. In patients with myocarditis complicated by dilated cardiomyopathy, echocardiography typically shows ventricular dilation and global ventricular hypokinesis.

Key learning point: Viral myocarditis can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy in young adults, presenting with acute decompensated heart failure symptoms such as dyspnea, edema, S3 gallop, and cardiomegaly on imaging.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, jugular venous distention, lower extremity edema, tachycardia, an S3 gallop, inspiratory crackles, and x-ray findings of pulmonary congestion (e.g., increased vascular markings, cardiac enlargement) are consistent with decompensated heart failure (HF). In this young and otherwise healthy patient with a history of recent upper respiratory tract infection and chest pain that increases during inspiration (indicating pericardial involvement), HF is most likely secondary to viral myocarditis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 5-day history of worsening dyspnea and intermittent chest pain that is worse with inspiration. He recently started training for a marathon and had an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. His temperature is 36.8°C, pulse is 113/min, and blood pressure is 110/74 mm Hg. On examination, there is jugular venous distention and lower extremity edema. Inspiratory crackles are present throughout the lung fields. Cardiac examination reveals an S3 gallop. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette and prominent vascular markings in both lung fields. Electrocardiography demonstrates diffuse T-wave inversions. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pericardial tamponade can be caused by a large pericardial effusion, for which viral myocarditis is a risk factor. This condition can cause hemodynamic compromise and jugular venous distention. However, other typical findings of pericardial tamponade include hypotension and distant heart sounds (see Beck triad). In addition, this condition typically causes low voltage and electrical alternans on ECG.

B) CORRECT:

Myocarditis has a wide range of clinical presentations, from subclinical (and often undiagnosed) myocarditis to dilated cardiomyopathy with features of acute decompensated heart failure, as seen in this patient. Myocarditis is most commonly caused by viral infections and most often affects young adults. If myocarditis is suspected, an ECG, cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponin), and chest x-ray should be obtained. ECG may show nonspecific signs of myocardial damage (e.g., T-wave inversions, tachycardia); cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponin I) and inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) are typically elevated. Echocardiography is indicated to evaluate ventricular dysfunction. In patients with myocarditis complicated by dilated cardiomyopathy, echocardiography typically shows ventricular dilation and global ventricular hypokinesis.

Key learning point: Viral myocarditis in young adults can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy, presenting with acute heart failure symptoms, ventricular dilation, and global hypokinesis on echocardiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve stenosis can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) since the left ventricle chronically pumps against a high afterload. While this patient shows signs of an enlarged left ventricle (enlarged cardiac silhouette), and LVH can cause T-wave inversions, he is otherwise young and healthy (no history of angina pectoris or syncopal episodes) and has no heart murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a hereditary disease and the leading cause of death in young athletes. This condition manifests with chest pain and dyspnea that worsen with strenuous exercise (due to reduced systolic output), which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, he is missing additional features of HCM, such as syncopal episodes, palpitations, and vertigo, and his ECG lacks signs of left ventricular hypertrophy (see Sokolow-Lyon criteria) or atrial fibrillation. Furthermore, jugular distention and inspiratory crackles are not expected in patients with HCM.

E) INCORRECT:

Vegetations on the cardiac valves in the setting of bacterial endocarditis can lead to valvular insufficiency and subsequent heart failure. However, endocarditis typically causes constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever) and a heart murmur, which are not present here.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, jugular venous distention, lower extremity edema, tachycardia, an S3 gallop, inspiratory crackles, and x-ray findings of pulmonary congestion (e.g., increased vascular markings, cardiac enlargement) are consistent with decompensated heart failure (HF). In this young and otherwise healthy patient with a history of recent upper respiratory tract infection and chest pain that increases during inspiration (indicating pericardial involvement), HF is most likely secondary to viral myocarditis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with chest pain and dyspnea that began 2 days ago. He had a flu-like illness 2 weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 108/68; P, 118; R, 22; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows an S3 gallop and bilateral inspiratory crackles. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-segment changes in multiple leads. Troponin is 4.2 ng/mL. Echocardiogram shows global hypokinesis with ejection fraction of 35% and a small pericardial effusion. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Admit for continous cardiac monitoring and heart failure management
Obtain cardiac MRI before further management
Discharge with NSAIDs for pain and cardiology follow-up

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with myocarditis complicated by acute heart failure, evidenced by dyspnea, S3 gallop, crackles, reduced ejection fraction, and elevated troponin. Hospitalization is required for cardiac monitoring, heart failure management, and assessment for complications such as arrhythmias or further deterioration.

B) INCORRECT:

While cardiac MRI can be useful for definitive diagnosis of myocarditis, this patient has acute heart failure requiring immediate hospitalization and stabilization. Advanced imaging can be obtained after initial management and stabilization are initiated.

C) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is not indicated because the pericardial effusion is small and there is no evidence of cardiac tamponade. This patient's clinical presentation with heart failure symptoms, global hypokinesis, and elevated troponin is more consistent with myocarditis than with pericardial disease.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has evidence of acute heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and requires inpatient monitoring. NSAIDs may also worsen heart failure.

E) INCORRECT:

While coronary angiography may be considered to exclude differential diagnoses, this patient's clinical presentation makes myocarditis more likely than a manifestation of coronary artery disease that requires immediate catheterization.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with 2 days of chest pain and dyspnea. She had flu-like symptoms 10 days ago. Vital signs are BP, 85/50; P, 120; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, S3 gallop, and bilateral lower extremity edema. ECG demonstrates sinus tachycardia with frequent ventricular premature beats. Troponin is elevated at 15 ng/mL. Echocardiogram shows diffuse hypokinesis with ejection fraction of 25%. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain cardiac MRI for definitive diagnosis
Give a 500-1000 ml IV fluid bolus
Transfer to advanced heart failure center

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids may be considered for specific causes of myocarditis under specialist guidance, but this is not the immediate priority.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI is useful for definitive diagnosis but is not the immediate priority in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A large-volume IV fluid bolus is contraindicated in this patient, who shows clear evidence of volume overload (jugular venous distension, S3 gallop, bilateral edema) and cardiogenic shock. Fluid bolus would worsen pulmonary edema and further compromise cardiac function. This patient's hypotension is due to poor cardiac output, not volume depletion.

D) INCORRECT:

Endomyocardial biopsy may be considered for diagnostic purposes but is not the immediate priority in an unstable patient.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with fulminant myocarditis, evidenced by classic myocarditis features plus hemodynamic instability (hypotension, signs of cardiogenic shock). Fulminant myocarditis requires urgent transfer to an advanced heart failure center with specialist myocarditis teams capable of providing intensive monitoring, inotropic support, and potentially mechanical circulatory support.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man who is an athlete presents with chest pain and dyspnea that began 3 days ago. He had a viral upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 115/75; P, 108; R, 22; oxygen saturation, 97% on room air. Cardiac examination shows regular rhythm with an S3 gallop. 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia with diffuse ST elevation and PR depression. Troponin I is elevated at 0.8 ng/mL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dual antiplatelet therapy is inappropriate for myocarditis and can increase bleeding risk. This patient's diffuse ST elevation with PR depression, young age, and recent viral illness are more consistent with myocarditis than with acute coronary syndrome, which typically shows regional ST changes.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is not indicated as the next immediate step. While coronary angiography may be considered to rule out differential diagnoses, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG findings are more consistent with myocarditis than with coronary artery disease.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Transthoracic echocardiography is the most appropriate next step after initial ECG and troponin results suggest myocarditis. Echocardiogram assesses for wall motion abnormalities, reduced ejection fraction, ventricular dilation, and complications such as pericardial effusion. This imaging is essential for risk stratification and to guide further management decisions, including the need for admission and monitoring.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose steroids are not part of routine myocarditis management and may be harmful in viral myocarditis, as they may worsen myocardial inflammation and delay healing.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI is not the most appropriate next step in the initial diagnostic workup. While cardiac MRI can confirm myocarditis and is used as a definitive diagnostic study, it is typically obtained after initial diagnostics.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is a runner presents with progressive dyspnea and chest discomfort over 3 days. She had a viral upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 90/55; P, 125; R, 22; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure, S3 gallop, and bilateral crackles. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with diffuse concave ST elevations. Troponin I is 0.9 ng/L. Echocardiogram shows global hypokinesis with ejection fraction of 30% and no regional wall motion abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain cardiac MRI before initiating treatment
Arrange urgent transfer to advanced heart failure center
Initiate ACE inhibitor therapy and discharge with cardiology follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While coronary artery disease should be considered in the differential, the clinical presentation (young patient, recent viral illness, diffuse ST changes rather than regional changes) and echocardiographic findings (global rather than regional dysfunction) suggest another diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI is used for diagnostic confirmation in stable patients when the diagnosis is uncertain. In hemodynamically unstable patients with high-risk features, management should not be delayed for advanced imaging studies.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids should only be initiated under specialist guidance after ruling out pathogenic infection, typically through endomyocardial biopsy.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation is consistent with myocarditis with high-risk features, including symptomatic heart failure and hemodynamic instability. Management involves urgent transfer to an advanced heart failure center for specialized cardiac care, continuous monitoring, and potentially circulatory support.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has symptomatic heart failure with hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia), representing high-risk features that require inpatient monitoring and specialist care. Both ACE inhibitors and discharge are inappropriate based on the potential for clinical deterioration.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male college athlete presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain is worse with inspiration and when lying flat. He reports having a febrile upper respiratory illness with myalgias about 10 days ago that resolved spontaneously. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), his pulse is 115/min, and his blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. On examination, a faint friction rub is heard at the left sternal border. An ECG shows diffuse ST-segment elevation. Laboratory studies show a troponin I level of 4.5 ng/mL (reference range <0.04 ng/mL). Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes can cause acute rheumatic fever, which may lead to carditis. However, rheumatic fever typically develops 2–4 weeks after a streptococcal pharyngitis, not a nonspecific upper respiratory illness. Furthermore, the classic presentation often includes other major criteria, such as migratory polyarthritis, which are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi, the agent of Lyme disease, can cause Lyme carditis. However, the most common cardiac manifestation of Lyme disease is atrioventricular conduction block, which is not seen on this patient's ECG. The diagnosis would also typically be suggested by a history of a tick bite or travel to an endemic area, which is not mentioned.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for acute myocarditis, an inflammation of both the myocardium and pericardium. The most common cause of myopericarditis is a viral infection, with enteroviruses, particularly Coxsackie B virus, being the most frequently identified pathogens. The recent history of a febrile upper respiratory illness serves as a typical viral prodrome. The pericarditis component is supported by the pleuritic and positional chest pain, pericardial friction rub, and diffuse ST-segment elevation. The myocarditis component is indicated by the elevated troponin, reflecting myocardial injury. Although many viruses can cause this condition, Coxsackie B virus is the most common cause in young, otherwise healthy individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of purulent pericarditis, which is a severe bacterial infection of the pericardial space. This condition typically arises from bacteremia, direct spread from pneumonia, or after cardiothoracic surgery. Patients with purulent pericarditis are usually critically ill with high fevers and signs of sepsis, a much more severe presentation than seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Influenza A is a known viral cause of myopericarditis and is associated with a preceding flu-like illness. However, enteroviruses are statistically more common causes of viral myocarditis than influenza viruses. Given the options, another pathogen is a more probable cause.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of pleuritic chest pain, a friction rub, diffuse ST-segment elevation, and elevated troponin levels is classic for acute myocarditis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 2-week history of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue. He also has difficulty breathing when lying flat and has noticed swelling in his ankles. He reports a flu-like illness about a month ago that resolved without treatment. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 22/min. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention and bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. Auscultation shows bibasilar crackles and an S3 gallop. An echocardiogram shows global hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 25%. In addition to diuretics, which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's heart failure is likely due to a preceding viral illness, antiviral therapy with acyclovir and oseltamivir is generally not effective. The most common viral causes of myocarditis (e.g., enteroviruses, parvovirus B19) do not have specific antiviral treatments. Furthermore, by the time heart failure symptoms develop, the acute viral infection has typically resolved, and the damage is due to the subsequent inflammatory response.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppressive therapy with corticosteroids or intravenous immunoglobulin might be considered for specific, noninfectious causes of myocarditis, such as giant cell myocarditis or sarcoidosis. However, for the most common cause, viral myocarditis, routine use of immunosuppression is not recommended and may even be harmful. The standard of care is supportive management and treatment of the resulting heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, such as diltiazem, have negative inotropic effects, meaning they weaken the contractility of the heart muscle. This property is detrimental in a patient with a severely reduced ejection fraction and is therefore contraindicated in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Aspirin is not indicated because there is no evidence of an ischemic cause for this patient's heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

These anti-inflammatory agents are used to treat pericarditis. Although myocarditis can have a pericardial component (myopericarditis), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen are contraindicated in acute heart failure. NSAIDs can cause sodium and water retention, impair renal function, and antagonize the effects of diuretics, thereby worsening heart failure.

E) CORRECT:

Guideline-directed medical therapy for acute HFrEF includes a beta-blocker (e.g., metoprolol) and a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitor, such as an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor like lisinopril. Beta-blockers counteract the detrimental effects of chronic sympathetic activation, while ACE inhibitors block angiotensin II production, reducing afterload and preload. Both classes of medications have been shown to reduce mortality and morbidity in HFrEF. They should be started at low doses once the patient is hemodynamically stable and titrated to target doses as tolerated.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with acute heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), likely from viral myocarditis. The cornerstone of management, once the patient is euvolemic, involves medications that block the neurohormonal systems responsible for disease progression.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue. He reports difficulty breathing when lying flat and has been sleeping propped up on three pillows. He also notes swelling in his ankles. About one month prior to the onset of these symptoms, he had a flu-like illness with fever and myalgias that resolved spontaneously. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention, bibasilar crackles, and an S3 gallop. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes heart failure with prominent signs of right-sided failure, such as jugular venous distention and edema. However, it is a rare cause of cardiomyopathy, typically associated with infiltrative diseases like amyloidosis or sarcoidosis, and is less likely in a previously healthy young man. It is a disorder of diastolic dysfunction, making an S3 gallop less common than an S4.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause dyspnea in a young adult. However, it is primarily a disorder of diastolic dysfunction due to a thickened, noncompliant myocardium. The classic physical examination finding is an S4 gallop, not an S3. Furthermore, the strong temporal association with a preceding viral illness is not a typical feature of this genetic disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary embolism can cause acute dyspnea and tachycardia. Although a massive embolism can lead to right heart failure with jugular venous distention, the presence of bibasilar crackles and an S3 gallop strongly suggests left-sided heart failure and pulmonary edema, which are not primary features of a pulmonary embolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Although a viral illness can precede acute pericarditis, the classic symptom is sharp, pleuritic chest pain that improves when leaning forward, which this patient does not report. The physical examination findings of bibasilar crackles, an S3 gallop, and significant peripheral edema are more indicative of myocardial failure and volume overload than primary pericardial inflammation.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of acute biventricular congestive heart failure is classic for dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), especially given the preceding viral prodrome. Viral myocarditis, often from Coxsackie B virus, can lead to myocardial inflammation and damage, resulting in ventricular dilation and impaired contractility (systolic dysfunction). This leads to signs of left-sided failure (orthopnea, bibasilar crackles) and right-sided failure (jugular venous distention, peripheral edema). The S3 gallop is a key finding, representing rapid, turbulent blood flow into a dilated, volume-overloaded ventricle. DCM is the most common cause of nonischemic cardiomyopathy and a frequent reason for heart failure in young adults.
questions.hint: This young patient's presentation of acute congestive heart failure is most likely a consequence of his recent viral illness, which can cause direct myocardial injury.
